abstract.p: Roberta E Weisbrod letter says sport utility vehicles not only pose a hazard to New York City's roads because of their size (front page July 2), but they also threaten the region's environment, human health and economy

block.p: Sport utility vehicles not only pose a hazard to New York City's roads because of their size, but they also threaten the region's environment, human health and economy (front page, July 2).
Sport utility vehicles not only pose a hazard to New York City's roads because of their size, but they also threaten the region's environment, human health and economy (front page, July 2).

S.U.V.'s emit 40 percent more air pollutants than cars and contribute to global warming through the release of greenhouse gases. The metropolitan area already has among the worst air quality in the country, with smog at a level second only to Los Angeles.

Poor air quality is beginning to hurt the region's economy. Because of its failure to reduce emissions, New Jersey has already been sanctioned by the Environmental Protection Agency, and if by December it hasn't improved its vehicle inspection program, then it could lose Federal money for transportation projects.
ROBERTA E. WEISBROD New York, July 2, 1999
The writer is director, Sustainable Transportation Program, Inform.
